awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Use of Machine Learning Techniques for Robust Crop and Weed Detection in Agricultural Fields
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project seeks to further develop a novel computer vision based plant identification system for commercialization in agricultural weed control. This system will provide a cost competitive alternative to chemical herbicides, a global $20B market. Existing computer vision based approaches can segment a 'splotch' of green vegetation from a brown background but are unable to provide the selectivity and precision necessary for mechanized, automated weeding. This project's objective is to create software algorithms that match the capability of the human eye and brain to quickly and reliably classify plants into crops and weeds in real-time. The project team will build a computer vision algorithm based on a hierarchical classifier. This classifier will utilize a field customized support vector machine (SVM) that uses point-of-interest rather than shape-based methods, a novel approach to visual object identification. The result of this research will be the creation of an algorithm integrated into an automated weeding system.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is significant, as the development of an alternative to chemical intensive agricultural weed control will impact technological understanding, create commercial opportunity, and positively impact society. Technologically, the project will advance the fields of computer vision and machine learning through development of a real-time, automated plant identification system based on point-of-interest and SVMs. Commercially, the system will offer conventional farmers an effective and chemical-free method to eliminate weeds, and it will offer organic farmers the first truly precise organic weed control method. The addressable market for weed control in food production is estimated to be $4B in the U.S. The system's ability to eliminate the use of chemical herbicides has a profound societal effect. U.S. farmers apply over 250M pounds of herbicide annually on corn and soybeans alone, with many unintended and detrimental side effects. Chemical concentrations in rivers, lakes and groundwater are rising, and the prevalence of herbicide resistant weeds is growing exponentially. An alternative to these chemicals limits society's exposure while protecting environmental integrity.

por.por_cntn:
The PI, Lee Redden, and team developed novel computer vision and machine learning systems to detect crops in outdoor environments. These efforts consisted of two main efforts. The first in high throughput, high accuracy field based phenotyping of corn. The second in a highly productive centimeter level precision plant-by-plant weeding device that operates in cotton but is expandable to other crops.

 

To enable these inventions, mass data collection efforts were undertaken where data carts, tractors and implements were operated from Australia, throughout the Midwest and the South for both phenotyping and weeding projects.

 

To enable highly accurate phenotyping, a stereo camera setup was developed that was capable of imaging plants many times, finding frame-to-frame correspondence, reconstructing 3D point clouds, taking into account individual frame occlusions and creating highly accurate measurements of stand count, spacing, stock thickness and leaf area. These metrics could then be used by a breeder to improve the selection of genetic strains. A deep learning system was developed and used in conjunction with many other classical computer vision techniques to deliver these methods. This work was our first big initiative with deep learning and point cloud processing including GPU computing.

 

Computer vision systems were developed for centimeter level precision weeding machines that operate in row crops. The first crop they are being developed for is cotton, but the technology is extensible to many other row crops including soybeans and corn. Deep learning methods were developed for robust weed vs crop vs background detection and segmentation. A very large data set was collected across Australia and the United States of cotton plants in various stages. Subsets of this data was labeled and is representative of the variation of cotton fields across the United States. The normal deep learning techniques did not do well enough on small plant detection, were not fast enough and were not robust enough in real world changing conditions. This caused us to need to develop a novel neural network design and training techniques. We did this for both bounding box and pixelwise detection methods. The final output was a model that did not need to be tweaked to operate in new conditions and if performance ever deteriorates, only new training data needs to be added.  

 

Over the course of the NSF SBIR grants, the PI and teams have developed machine that operated on 10% of the lettuce in the United States, the highest accuracy field based phenotyping machine on the market and the most accurate weeding machine in existence.
